title: IRC Archive for channel #xwiki - XWiki
content:

07:47 <cjdelisle> "the reliability of local storage outweighs the benefits of EBS" ouch

08:18 <ihalip> has quit  
08:29 <mpaun> nice prank :)  
08:29 <mpaun> although could be real with voice recognition techniques  
08:30 <cjdelisle> yea, questionable how useful though.  
08:32 <cjdelisle> It occurs to me that we would get a dramatic performance improvement from the cluster by biasing the load balancer so that the same pages are usually loaded from the same node.  
08:33 <cjdelisle> Decreases cache churn and makes the total available cache become the sum of all caches in the cluster.  
08:35 <sburjan> has joined #xwiki  
08:36 <cjdelisle> http://i.imgur.com/efuc4.png  
08:48 <pulasthi> has joined #xwiki

08:53 <cjdelisle> cloudy mysql  
08:57 <+sburjan> cjdelisle: check freedodes MOTD :))  
08:58 <cjdelisle> and disconnect my perfectly good tcp connection?  
08:58 <+sburjan> :)  
08:58 <+sburjan> if it's good, leave it that way:)  
08:59 <cjdelisle> idle     : 0 days 0 hours 0 mins 17 secs [signon: Mon Feb 28 10:25:04 2011]  
09:01 <florinciu> has joined #xwiki  
09:22 <tmortagne> has joined #xwiki  
09:28 <arkub> has joined #xwiki  
10:22 <+sburjan> MySQL is getting on my nerves  
10:23 <cjdelisle> hehehe  
10:23 <cjdelisle> it is super effective  
10:23 <cjdelisle> http://source.mysema.com/forum/mvnforum/viewthread\_thread,49  
10:24 <+sburjan> either ubuntu's installer is idiot, because it seems I am not able to set a god damn root password  
10:24 <cjdelisle> ^that is a very interesting thread.  
10:24 <cjdelisle> oh that.  
10:24 <cjdelisle> sudo su  
10:24 <cjdelisle> l00phole  
10:24 <cjdelisle> but then make sure to set a passwd you'll remember (and before someone else does!)  
10:25 <+sburjan> I'm already su in system  
10:25 <+sburjan> :)  
10:25 <cjdelisle> oh right mysl is different.  
10:25 <cjdelisle> postgres just uses the same username as your system user.  
10:25 <+sburjan> i keep getting : ERROR 1045 (28000): Access denied for user 'root'@'localhost' (using password: NO)  
10:26 <+sburjan> and I've set a root password upon install. I also tried sudo dpkg-reconfigure mysql-server-5.1  
10:27 <cjdelisle> http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/resetting-permissions.html  
10:28 <cjdelisle> Thinking about it, I actually like the ident system better.  
10:28 <cjdelisle> su postgres  
10:28 <cjdelisle> psql  
10:29 <cjdelisle> nicer security properties.  
10:30 <+sburjan> I guess mysql user from system created by the installer should have a password set ? Or it has one already set by the installer ?  
10:30 <+sburjan> I am talking about the user who runs mysqld on the system. in my case it's mysql  
10:32 <cjdelisle> you can reset the "root" password by starting the mysql server with an init file containing a password update instruction.  
10:32 <+tmortagne> sburjan: nop no passwd by default  
10:32 <+tmortagne> if there is one it's that you set it at some point  
10:33 <+sburjan> ok. I am trying to track down the problem. why my ubuntu installer doesn't setthe root passwd (or any) root passwd when the installer asks me express for one :)  
10:33 <+tmortagne> don't know i never set one its always too much of a pain after :)  
10:34 <+tmortagne> but i'm not taking care of critical servers either ;)  
10:34 <+sburjan> ok. So I guess I'll have to bypass mysql conf to allow me to login without a root password :)  
10:35 <+sburjan> dunno if that's possible  
10:35 <+tmortagne> well the password is not in the conf but in the database  
10:35 <+tmortagne> I think  
10:35 <+sburjan> I know. But i can't get there :))  
10:35 <kasun> has quit  
10:36 <+tmortagne> your mysql contains importat stuff already ?  
10:36 <cjdelisle> http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/resetting-permissions.html <-- how to reset root password if it's lost...  
10:36 <+tmortagne> otherwise just apt-get remove --purge it and reinstall  
10:36 <+sburjan> tmortagne: no, I just installed it :)  
10:36 <+sburjan> tmortagne: yes, purged, now re-downloading :D  
10:36 <+tmortagne> when it ask for password don't provide it  
10:36 <+sburjan> let's see if --purge solves anything :)  
10:37 <+tmortagne> that's what i always do and it work well  
10:37 <+sburjan> oh.. didn't try that :D  
10:37 <+sburjan> thanks :)  
10:37 <+tmortagne> just let black and type enter basically  
10:37 <+tmortagne> blanck  
10:38 <+sburjan> tmortagne: ok, not working. I'm gonna dig in conf file  
10:38 <+tmortagne> what's not working ?  
10:39 <+sburjan> xwiki@xwiki-desktop:~/Desktop$ mysql -u root test  
10:39 <+sburjan> ERROR 1045 (28000): Access denied for user 'root'@'localhost' (using password: NO)  
10:40 <+tmortagne> did you uninstalled it with purge ?  
10:40 <+sburjan> yeah  
10:40 <+tmortagne> do you have something in /var/lib/mysql/ after uninstall ?  
10:40 <+tmortagne> maybe puurge only handle conf  
10:40 <+tmortagne> for mysql  
10:40 <+tmortagne> and not databases  
10:40 <+sburjan> ok. i'll rm -rf the dir :)  
10:40 <+tmortagne> if that's the case then remove them by hand after uninstall  
10:41 <+sburjan> maybe I have to reboot like in windows (joking)  
10:41 <+tmortagne> :)  
10:42 <cjdelisle> if you remember what passwd you used you could just login with it.  
10:43 <+sburjan> i remember the passwd, but it seems that the great installer doesn't use the one I give  
10:43 <+sburjan> also, blank password doesn't work either, see above :)  
10:43 <cjdelisle> mysql -u root -p  
10:43 <cjdelisle> ?  
10:43 <florinciu> has quit  
10:43 <+tmortagne> sburjan: blanck passwork will not work if you have a password set  
10:44 <+sburjan> tmortagne: /var/lib/mysql is not blank :)  
10:44 <+tmortagne> what do you mean ?  
10:44 <+sburjan> root@xwiki-desktop:/var/lib# rm -rf mysql/  
10:44 <+sburjan> this :)  
10:44 <+sburjan> lets try again :D  
10:45 <+tmortagne> s/not/now/ ?  
10:45 <fmancinelli> has joined #xwiki  
10:46 <+sburjan> same thing, LOL  
10:46 <+sburjan> cjdelisle: works with your command :)  
10:46 <cjdelisle> mysq 2 sb 0  
10:46 <+sburjan> I was able to login as root  
10:47 <+tmortagne> sburjan: i don't understand, you set a password then  
10:47 <cjdelisle> ^that was how I felt when I used myswl.  
10:47 <+sburjan> tmortagne: NO, i didn't .. left the passwd field blank and pressed enter  
10:47 <+sburjan> ok. now it works  
10:48 <+sburjan> dunno wtf happend  
10:48 <+tmortagne> hmm  
10:48 <cjdelisle> It wants something, even if it's nothing.  
10:49 <+tmortagne> it always worked for me, i don't understand how you can have a password you did not set  
10:49 <cjdelisle> a single line in postgres.conf :P  
10:49 <+sburjan> tmortagne: works with sudo mysql -u root  
10:49 <+sburjan> so I don't have a password set  
10:49 <+tmortagne> though you were using -p  
10:50 <+sburjan> no, it seems works without -p  
10:50 <+tmortagne> since you were talking about cjdelisle command  
10:50 <+sburjan> but still don't understand why do I have to sudo  
10:50 <+sburjan> ah, works without sudo too  
10:50 <+sburjan> ok. thanks for helping  
10:50 <+tmortagne> ha so it's works then :)  
10:51 <+sburjan> I will update the tutorial with this problem :)  
10:51 <+sburjan> or provide a link you gave me  
10:51 <+tmortagne> there is a ubuntu tutorial ? Not sure it's a good advice to tell people to not use a password for root :)  
10:51 <+sburjan> ok, I won't then :)  
10:52 <rrodriguez> has joined #xwiki  
10:54 <+tmortagne> just indicate that the provided command example to set xwiki mysql user is when there is no password for root and that you need to use -p if there is one  
10:54 <+tmortagne> ( sburjan )  
10:55 <+sburjan> I really LOVE the output console of select \* from mysql.user;  
10:55 <+sburjan> it's so epic I can't understand nothing :))  
10:56 <+sburjan> because of formatting issues ofc  
10:57 <+tmortagne> you use use MySQL Administrator  
10:57 <+sburjan> yes, I was about to install it now :)  
10:57 <+tmortagne> and MySQL Query Browser  
10:57 <cjdelisle> fmancinelli: I found some interesting things re cloud storage.  
10:57 <cjdelisle> http://www.datanucleus.org/products/accessplatform\_2\_2/googlestorage/features.html  
10:57 <+tmortagne> s/use use/should use/  
10:57 <+sburjan> also, select user from mysql.user; lists 3 times root :) is t his normal ? :)  
10:58 <cjdelisle> Note this nasty little line: "Yes, but all candidates retrieved from datastore, and then evaluated in-memory"  
10:58 <+sburjan> that would be the number of reinstalls I've done :D  
10:58 <+tmortagne> sburjan: root@localhost, roo@% etc are differents users form mysql  
10:58 <+tmortagne> s/form/for/  
10:59 <+sburjan> yes, but I only get them as root, no @ no nothing  
11:00 <+tmortagne> because you only selected user column ;)  
11:00 <+sburjan> yeah :D  
11:00 <+tmortagne> if you don't want all the entries you have to use "distinct"  
11:00 <+sburjan> or select host, user from mysql.user;  
11:01 <+tmortagne> "if you don't want all the entries" ;)  
11:01 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: yep, seen it. Though the problem is how to make the "model" interoperable between different platform... If you've seen the little test I've sent you, even a little change could screw things up  
11:01 <+sburjan> yes, works that too. :)  
11:01 <+tmortagne> but much easier in UI  
11:01 <+sburjan> I've installed mysql several times but never had the chance to play with it  
11:02 <+tmortagne> (even if ok using the UI is bad because then you don't know the mysql command :))  
11:02 <evalica> has joined #xwiki  
11:02 <+sburjan> true. you have to suffer using the console. But I like more the console  
11:03 <+tmortagne> well depends what i need to do  
11:03 <cjdelisle> fmancinelli: I'm looking at the test code now. I see api lockin but I don't see lockin to a particular store. I suppose you also read about the politics between the JDO and JPA people.  
11:04 <cjdelisle> Also not sure if you have heard of this: http://source.mysema.com/forum/mvnforum/viewthread\_thread,49  
11:05 <cjdelisle> If I were calling all of the shots, I would want that to be the new standard way of doing queries.  
11:05 <cjdelisle> (probably off topic)  
11:05 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: what I meant is that depending on how you put JDO annotations in your classes, the code might work with a store but not with another. So it's not completely transparent  
11:06 <cjdelisle> I will have to look over that again. One thing I really like is the consept of bytecode tinkering so that we don't need to pollute everything with getters and setters.  
11:06 <fmancinelli> yep  
11:07 <+sburjan> tmortagne: one last question. In the tutorial we state than XEM and XWiki needs InnoDB and \_not\_ MyISAM. Where is the "switch" to do this, because I can't see it in the tutorial. Or the setting is made from the hibernate conf file we have on the tutorial page ?  
11:07 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: anyway what I sent you is the final result of several attempts to put the right annotations in the right places so that RDBMS and Cassandra stores could be swapped without any problem  
11:08 <+tmortagne> sburjan: i don't know why this documentation say that, i never setup that  
11:08 <+tmortagne> IMO you can remove that part  
11:08 <cjdelisle> Ahh, I see. So it really is very fragile.  
11:08 <+tmortagne> sburjan: ask alex maybe if  it's really important  
11:09 <cjdelisle> Perhaps we can implement some kind of validator. This would be difficult and time consuming to get right unless we used a "try everything" validator.  
11:09 <rrodriguez> has quit  
11:10 <cjdelisle> Re Cassandra, read about that and I agree that it is definitly the future.  
11:10 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: not sure... but it's a very interesting topic to do research about :)  
11:11 <cjdelisle> I suppose if there was something else out there I have not heard about then perhaps it might lose to it but against rdbms and jcr my money is on cassandra.  
11:12 <cjdelisle> I found this interesting: http://blog.reddit.com/2011/03/why-reddit-was-down-for-6-of-last-24.html  
11:12 <cjdelisle> A real life case of a system using postgres and cassandra in the amazon cloud.  
11:12 <cjdelisle> And how it failed when lots of disks failed at once.  
11:13 <cjdelisle> \*They used to be 100% postgres but are apparently migrating to cassandra.  
11:22 <abusenius> has joined #xwiki  
11:22 <Enygma`> has joined #xwiki  
11:27 <Enygma`> has quit  
11:27 <Enygma`> has joined #xwiki  
11:29 <kasun> has joined #xwiki  
11:32 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: sure cassandra is more fault tolerant (it's replicated and eventually consistent)... though it's data model is very different (you can have a look at this good article: http://arin.me/blog/wtf-is-a-supercolumn-cassandra-data-model). Though the fact that is eventually consistent might be an issue for some use cases... I mean, having a status on a facebook wall appear after one hour for everyone it's fine. Having a design docu  
11:37 <+sburjan> tmortagne: I am referring to this : http://platform.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/AdminGuide/InstallationMySQL  Read at the beginning  
11:39 <+tmortagne> sburjan: ok but really i never change the Mysql database engine and never had any issue, i don't know  why there is this in this documentation  
11:39 <+tmortagne> unless it's for old mysql or something like that  
11:40 <+tmortagne> look slike it's only for transaction  
11:41 <+tmortagne> it's probably safer to use engine which support transaction but we are kind of used to MyISAM now...  
11:41 <+tmortagne> all i'm saying is that it's really not a critical requirement  
11:42 <cjdelisle> fmancinelli: you were cut off here: "one hour for everyone it's fine. Having a design docu|<--  
11:42 <+tmortagne> "most likely corrupt your database" is a bit too much...  
11:42 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: ... I mean, having a status on a facebook wall appear after one hour for everyone it's fine. Having a design document in an intranet appear with the same delay could not be acceptable :)  
11:42 <+tmortagne> sburjan: it's certainly totally useless for a test  
11:43 <cjdelisle> Immediet consistancy means locking everyone out until the database becomes consistant which is unreasonable.  
11:44 <cjdelisle> So some kind of eventual consistancy plan is needed, the way to make that not be a problem is to direct all requests (get and put) for a given page to a given node.  
11:45 <cjdelisle> Oddly enough I have some experience with this key:value stuff because I am working on a dht based dns engine in my "free time".  
11:47 <cjdelisle> If we had an xwiki installation on top of each node then we could use the load balancer to direct traffic to the one who's id is closest to the id of the document.  
11:48 <evalica> has quit  
11:48 <cjdelisle> Ofc then we can skip the cloud stuff entirely, use a little hsql installation under each one, and sync them through jgroups.  
11:49 <cjdelisle> ^which I understand is not the goal ;)  
11:50 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: or use mysql replication :)  
11:51 <+sburjan> tmortagne: I understood your POV. I will have to ask someone or try to dig deeper if that text should be there. IMO it complicates the XEM installation process (may confuse users). So if it isn't necessary for production, we should remove it in order to simplify the tech details for installing XEM.  
11:51 <sdumitriu> has joined #xwiki  
11:52 <cjdelisle> Back to the cloud thinking. Maybe I spoke too soon to say "cassandra is the future" but I do think key:value is. Rdbms just can never be as fast or scale as well.  
11:53 <cjdelisle> key:value and eventual consistance over the whole group.  
11:54 <cjdelisle> But if each storage engine is also an xwiki node then it's not much of an issue as long as requests for a given page always go to a given node.  
11:55 <cjdelisle> In addition it maximizes the effectiveness of the xwiki cache.  
11:56 <cjdelisle> But for searches, consistancy can't really be immediet.  
11:56 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: anyway, besides speculations, I think that datanucleus+JDO is a valid alternative to explore  
11:57 <cjdelisle> Agreed, what I'm trying to determine now is whether there is going to be compatability issues between JDO and JPA specifically XWQL.  
12:00 <+sburjan> tmortagne: from your XEM experience, the user you are granding XEM db priviledges, must be "xwiki" or can be another one also ? I am looking also at the hibernate config, you'll have to put the custom user there too. But besides that, is there any other constraint ?  
12:00 <+tmortagne> sburjan: can be anything  
12:00 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: AFAIK, JDO is more generic and (almost) a superset of JPA with some minor API differences, mostly in method signatures (http://db.apache.org/jdo/jdo\_v\_jpa.html)  
12:00 <+sburjan> good. I will mention that in the documentation  
12:01 <+tmortagne> basically the only difference between XE and XEM around mysql is the target database name handling  
12:01 <+tmortagne> (around any database engine actually)  
12:02 <+sburjan> yes, the way XE databases are named I guess  
12:03 <+sburjan> because they have to be uniquely identified  
12:03 <cjdelisle> Hmm so use jdo to store then query using jpaql?  
12:05 <cjdelisle> Anyway, I was thinking about storage for xwiki objects and it seems like the most eligent solution might just be to craft a java class from the xwiki class and feed it to the bytecode modifier then persist it with datanucleas.  
12:06 <cjdelisle> I will work on testing to see if this is feasable.  
12:07 <cjdelisle> If it works, we might get pure jpaql to behave just like xwql simply by the way we persist objects.  
12:16 <pulasthi> fmancinelli : hi  
12:16 <fmancinelli> pulasthi: hi  
12:17 <pulasthi> fmancinelli : so i wenr though the data model and im now looking at XWQL  
12:18 <pulasthi> so from what i understand ur datais handled as objects right  
12:18 <cjdelisle> http://source.mysema.com/static/querydsl/2.1.1/reference/html/ch02.html#d0e172  
12:18 <cjdelisle> mmmmmmm  
12:18 <cjdelisle> make db injection impossible :)  
12:19 <pulasthi>  cjdelisle: was the link for me ?  
12:19 <cjdelisle> pulasthi: The way it currently works is we pull data from the db and build objects.  
12:20 <pulasthi> ya i understood that  
12:20 <cjdelisle> umm sure if you like (it's sort of related)  
12:20 <cjdelisle> We don't really store data in tables. We kind of implent an overlay database.  
12:21 <pulasthi> cjdelisle : so what the project wants is to replicate ur database in appengine?  
12:21 <cjdelisle> I assume you saw the data model?  
12:21 <fmancinelli> pulashti: yes, we use hibernate ORM to persist and retrieve objects to from the DB  
12:21 <pulasthi> cjdelisle: ya i went though the datamodel wiki on the site  
12:22 <cjdelisle> And you saw the tables xwikistrings, xwikiintegers xwikilongs etc. etc.  
12:22 <pulasthi> cjdelisle : ya  
12:22 <pulasthi> thats the mysql database right  
12:22 <cjdelisle> Since we allow the user to simply define their own classes, it was decided to mack the database instead of making a table for each class.  
12:22 <pulasthi> so u pull data from it when needed and make objects  
12:23 <cjdelisle> \*mock  
12:23 <cjdelisle> If we move to a key:value based storage mechanism then that will be redundant.  
12:23 <cjdelisle> Yes that's for mysql/hibernate  
12:24 <pulasthi> so all ur data is in the mysql database or only a part of it  
12:24 <cjdelisle> All is in the database.  
12:24 <cjdelisle> Have you seen the hibernate mapping file?  
12:25 <cjdelisle> http://svn.xwiki.org/svnroot/xwiki/platform/core/trunk/xwiki-core/src/main/resources/xwiki.hbm.xml  
12:25 <cjdelisle> That explains in grusome detale how the storage mapping works.  
12:25 <cjdelisle> There are 2 cases.  
12:25 <pulasthi> ahh ok  
12:26 <cjdelisle> 1. The class is "custom mapped" and thus our engine made a db table for it.  
12:27 <cjdelisle> 2. The class is not custom mapped and each of it's fields (called "properties") are stored in the strings/integers/longs/etc tables.  
12:28 <cjdelisle> In my opinion, if this is not the best solution then we shouldn't hold on to it for historical reasons.  
12:29 <pulasthi> so is mirating to app engine kind of a solution to this  
12:29 <pulasthi> the way data is handled will be chaged a bit there right  
12:30 <cjdelisle> I think it's important that we don't migrate in such a way that we become locked in to the app engine.  
12:31 <cjdelisle> bigtable looks nice but all of that niceness means we would make ourselves incompatable.  
12:31 <pulasthi> so the implenetaion should in a way you can jump out of the app engine if needed  
12:31 <pulasthi> without being completety app engine specific

13:03 <cjdelisle> Well there are multiple ways around it, each have their own problems.

13:39 <cjdelisle> Here's a crazy idea: instead of the url being: http://www.xwiki.org/bin/view/Main/WebHome it should be http://xwiki.Main.WebHome.xwiki.org/view  
13:39 <cjdelisle> That way load balancing can be done by dns and the same page will always be served by the same node in the cluster.  
13:40 <@sdumitriu> cjdelisle: Won't that put a lot of load on the dns?

13:40 <cjdelisle> dns can take it. Also isps will cache the entries which makes it free.
